question: A 24-year-old African American female presents in the 35th week of an uncomplicated pregnancy with numbness and burning in her right palm. She says the sensation is so uncomfartable that it frequently makes it difficult to sleep. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
explanation:
This patient presents with paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, making carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), a median nerve compression neuropathy, the most likely diagnosis. CTS symptoms are worsened by manual activity and often wake the patient from sleep. Repetitive wrist flexion and extension is the usual cause of CTS. The incidence is increased in pregnancy secandary to an estrogen-mediated depolymerization of ground substance, which causes interstitial edema in the hands (and face) and thus increased pressure within the carpal tunnel. Prolonged or repetitive wrist flexion and extension alsa increase carpal tunnel pressure. Therefore, the initial treatment is a neutral position wrist splint.
(Choice A) While NSAIDs may decrease the pain assaciated with carpal tunnel syndrome, their use during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of miscarriage and may promote premature closure af the fetal ductus arteriosus.
{Choices B & C) When splinting and analgesics fail to relieve CTS symptoms, direct injection of carticosteraids into the carpal tunnel may help.
(Choice E) For CTS symptoms resistant to conservative interventions, ar if hand weakness and thenar muscle atrophy progresses, then apen or endoscopic surgical decompression of the carpal tunnel is indicated.
Educational objective:
Faresthesias or pain in the distribution of the median nerve during pregnancy is likely to be due to carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). Initial treatments far CTS invalve neutral position wrist splinting and NSAIDs. Local corticosteroid injection is indicated in cases where wrist splinting is insufficient to relieve symptoms. Surgical decompression of the carpal tunnel is reserved for cases when conservative management fails.

question: A 27-year-old female at 30 weeks gestation complains of difficulty hearing, especially on the right side. She denies any ear pain or discharge. Her pregnancy was complicated by acute pyelonephritis at 22 weeks gestation, which was treated with antibiotics. She does not smoke or consume alcohol, and she eats a balanced diet. She has no preexisting medical problems and takes no medications aside from a multivitamin. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and heart rate is 75/min. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. No focal abnormalities are found on neurologic examination. When a tuning fork is placed on the right mastoid process, she appreciates the tone louder than when it is held near the external auditory meatus. Audiometry shows right low-frequency hearing loss. Which of the following is the mast likely cause of this patient's complaints?
explanation:
The above vignette describes the Rinne test in which a tuning fark is placed over the mastoid process and then to the ear. In a normal patient, the tone is typically louder when placed next to the ear as opposed to on the mastoid process, indicating increased air conduction compared to bane conduction. Bone conduction that is greater than air conduction in an ear with hearing loss is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. The normal finding of air greater than bone conduction can also be found in sensorineural hearing loss. This test can be used in conjunction with the Weber test, which helps to localize the side of decreased hearing by placing the tuning fork in the midline of the face and asking the patient which side sounds louder. The most likely diagnosis in this particular case is otosclerosis, and the patient's pregnancy and recent episode of pyelonephritis are likely unrelated. Otosclerosis is the most common cause of conductive hearing loss in adults, and is most common in patients in their 20's and 30's. There is a slight female predominance. In atosclerosis, the stapes footplate becomes fixed to the aval window, resulting in loss of its piston action. This disorder is sometimes also referred to as otospongiosis because CT may show a lucent (as opposed to sclerotic) focus in the temporal bone near the oval window. Therefore, CT could be used to confirm the diagnosis in this case.
(Choice A) Ototoxic antibiotics such as aminoglycosides usually result in sensorineural as opposed to conductive hearing loss.
(Choice B) This patient's high blood pressure will likely require further evaluation and treatment, but it is unlikely to be contributing ta her hearing loss.
(Choice C) Meniere's disease affects the inner ear and typically presents with aural fullness, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss.
(Choice E) Chronic otitis media may cause conductive hearing loss, but it is typically accompanied by pain and can easily be diagnosed by otoscopic examination.
(Choice F) An acoustic neuroma, also known as a vestibular schwannoma, typically results in sensorineural hearing loss.
(Choice G) Presbycusis is sensorineural hearing loss that occurs in adults with advanced age.
Educational objective:
Bone conduction that is greater than air conduction on the Rinne test is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. The most commaon cause of conductive hearing loss in adults (particularly young adults) is otosclerosis.

question: A 29-year-old woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is 10 weeks pregnant as determined by her last menstrual period. She does nat have any medical problems and does not take any medications. She is devoutly religious and has been in a monogamous relationship with her husband since getting married 5 years aga. They live in a house built in 1983 where she works as a homemaker. Her husband is an accountant. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following screening tests is indicated at this time?
options: D. Red blood cell folic acid level
explanation:
It is recommended that all pregnant women be screened for syphilis regardless of risk factors. Screening should be performed at the first prenatal visit and is typically accomplished via the rapid plasma reagin (FPR) ar venereal disease research laboratory (WVDRL) test. When the screening test is positive, the diagnosis can be confirmed with the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test. Treatment is with penicillin.
(Choice B) There is no indication for hepatitis C screening in low-risk adults, pregnant or otherwise. This patient does nat have any obvious risk factors for hepatitis C infection.
(Choice C) The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends against testing lead levels in asymptomatic pregnant women. The incidence of lead toxicity in the United States is low and there are no studies to suggest that screening and treatment of asymptomatic pregnant women is beneficial.
(Choice D) Folic acid deficiency early in pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects in newborns. The USPSTF and other organizations recommend that women of child-bearing age eat a diet rich in falic acid and/or take a folic acid supplement. Routine testing of folic acid levels is not indicated, however.
(Choice E) The USFSTF recommends screening for Chlamydia infection in all women age 24 and younger and those at increased risk (history of sexual transmitted infections, new or multiple partners). This pregnant woman is nat at increased risk and thus does not require screening.
Educational objective:
Screening for syphilis is strongly recommended in all pregnant wamen, regardless of their risk factors far sexually transmitted infections.

question: A 35-year-old female complains of nipple discharge. The discharge is from both breasts, brown in color and accurs intermittently. She has two children who are 5 and 8 years old. She has nat been recently pregnant. Her last menstrual period was one week ago. She describes no other symptoms. Examination shows normal breasts without palpable lumps ar nipple abnormalities. Brownish discharge is expressed from the nipples, and it is guaiac negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: D. Serum prolactin and TSH levels
explanation:
The woman's nipple discharge is most consistent with galactorrhea. Galactorrhea presents as bilateral nipple discharge that is most often milky or clear in color, but can also be yellow, brown, or green. Further evaluation for the causes of galactorrhea should thus be pursued in this patient via testing of serum prolactin and TSH levels.
The red flags to watch out for in cases of nipple discharge are unilateral secretion, guaiac positive fluid, and breast lump. In the case of bilateral guaiac negative discharge, and in the absence of a breast mass, mammography is not necessary. The patient can be reassured that breast cancer is very unlikely.
Pregnancy, another camman cause of bilateral nipple discharge, is unlikely given that the patient had her LMP ane week ago.
(Choice A) Mammography is used both in screening for breast cancer, and in evaluating certain cases of breast lump or nipple discharge. If this patient had blood or guaiac positive fluid in her nipple discharge, or a breast lump an exam, mammagraphy would be indicated.
(Choice B) Ultrasonogram is one test that can be used in the evaluation of a breast mass. It is most useful at discerning fluid-filled masses from solid masses, evaluating the denser breast tissue of younger women, and in guided biopsies. Ultrasound is not part of the wark-up for galactorrhea.
(Choice C) Cytologic examination is indicated in cases of uniductal and quaiac positive nipple discharge. It allows the pathologist to examine cells from the duct to distinguish carcinoma, praliferative changes, and inflammatory processes. Itis nat indicated for guaiac negative discharge.
(Choice E) Surgical evaluation would have been indicated for this patient had her nipple discharge invalved grass blood, tested guaiac positive, ar been associated with a breast lump.
(Choice F) Galactorrhea has many potential causes. Depending on the etiology, it can be associated with infertility and other health issues. Further testing is indicated.
Educational objective:
Galactarrhea presents as guaiac negative bilateral nipple discharge. Prolactinoma, hypothyroidism, averstimulation of the nipple, oral contraceptive pills, and medications which lower dopamine levels are comman causes. Workup includes ruling out pregnancy, measuring serum prolactin and TSH levels, and possible MRI of the brain to rule out prolactinoma.

question: A 19-year-old primigravid woman at 34 weeks' gestation presents far a routine prenatal visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated to date. Her past medical history is unremarkable. She takes one multivitamin and ane iron tablet daily. She has no known drug allergies. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with 34 weeks gestational age. Routine clean-catch urine culture grows greater than 100,000 calonies/mL of Escherichia coli. Which of the following is the mast appropriate pharmacatherapy?
explanation:
This woman has asymptomatic bacteriuria, a positive urine culture in the absence of urinary tract symptoms. Guidelines dictate that pregnant women with asymptomatic bacteriuria should be treated with antibiotics in order to decrease invasive urinary tract infections, preterm deliveries, and low birth weight children. The evidence for treatment is most robust far women between 12 and 16 weeks' gestation, but some autharities extend this recommendation throughout pregnancy. Far a woman in the third trimester of pregnancy, the recommended antibiotics are amaxicilling nitrofurantoin, or an oral cephalosparin.
(Choice B) Ciprofloxacin is a first-line agent in the treatment of pyelonephritis and may also be used far uncomplicated cystitis in non-pregnant adults. Fluaroguinolones are class C drugs in pregnancy because they have the potential to cause arthropathy in the unborn fetus.
{Choice C) Clindamycin is a class B medication in pregnancy. While it would probably be safe far this woman, it is a poar chaice for urinary tract infections because it has no gram negative coverage.
(Choice D) Doxycycline and other tetracycline antibiotics are class D medications in pregnancy. They interfere with tooth development and should not be used in the secand half of pregnancy or in children less than B years of age.
{Choice E) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazale is a class C medication in pregnancy. It may be used during the second trimester but is not recommended for use during the first trimester because it interferes with folic acid metabalism ar during the third trimester because it increases the risk of kernicterus in the newborn.
Educational objective:
It is strongly recommended that asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant women be treated, especially women at 12-16 weeks' gestation. Recommended antibiotics include amoxicillin, nitrofurantain, and aral cephalosporins.

question: A 22-year-old woman is being followed by her family physician during her first pregnancy. She is currently at 28 weeks’ gestation, feeling well, and gaining an appropriate amount of weight. She has not had sexual intercourse far the past 15 weeks. Her first prenatal exam was at 12 weeks’ gestation, at which time her HIV, chlamydia, gonorrhea, Rh{D}-antibody, and urine cultures were negative. Her blood type is A negative. She does not know who the father of the child is but is excited to raise the child with the help of her mather. She is unable to recall or confirm her immunization status for a number of vaccines. Which of the following measures is warranted at this time?
explanation:
The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) strongly recommends Rh-blood typing and testing for Rh antibodies at the first prenatal visit, as well as repeat Rh antibody testing at 28 weeks’ in unsensitized women with Rh-pasitive ar Rh-unknown partners. This particular patient is Rh-negative and does not know the father's Rh status; thus, her Rh antibody status should be rechecked at this time.
(Choice A) In pregnant women whose immunization status is unknown ar unconfirmed, the physician should check for rubella immunity. However, the live MMR vaccine is not recommended for pregnant women. Instead, susceptible individuals should be advised to avoid individuals potentially infected with rubella.
(Choice B) Screening and treatment for asymptomatic bacteriuria between 12 and 16 weeks’ gestation significantly decreases symptomatic urinary tract infections, lower birth weight babies, and preterm deliveries, and is strongly recommended by the USPSTF. This woman has already been screened and is not known to have predisposing risk factors for recurrent urinary tract infections like urinary tract anomalies, sickle cell disease, etc.
(Choice D) The USF STF strongly recommends that pregnant women be screened for HIV infection at the first prenatal visit because early initiation of anti-retroviral medications can significantly decrease disease transmission to the fetus. This patient had a negative test at her first visit and, given her lack of new expasures, does not need to be rescreened.
(Choice E) It is recommended that pregnant women be vaccinated against influenza but not against PNEeumococcUs.
Educational objective:
Af the first prenatal visit, blood typing and Rh antibody testing (in Rh-negative women) should be performed. Unsensitized Rh-negative women potentially carrying an Rh-positive fetus should have their Rh antibody status retested between 24 and 28 weeks’ gestation. Patients at risk of alloimmunization should be given anti-Rh immune glabin at 28 weeks and again at the time of delivery.

question: A 28-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician for her first prenatal visit. She is at 8 weeks' gestation as determined by her last menstrual period. She has no medical problems and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes and stopped drinking alcohol when she decided to become pregnant. She has na history of illicit drug use and has never been diagnosed with a sexually transmitted disease. She has been in a monogamous relationship with her husband for the past ane year. Her family history is unremarkable. Her BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her physical examination, including vital signs, is within normal limits. Which of the following preventive measures is warranted at this visit?
explanation:
The Centers for Disease Cantrol (COC) recommend that all pregnant wamen without contraindications receive the influenza vaccination.
(Choice B) Hemoglobin electrophoresis is only recommended far patients at high risk for transmitting a hemaoglobinopathy based on family history, and is not routine.
(Choice C) There is no indication for the routine evaluation of hepatitis C status in patients at low risk.
(Choice D) The USF STF recommends that all pregnant women age 24 and younger, as well as alder pregnant women at elevated risk {new or multiple partners, history of sexually transmitted infections, etc), be screened far chlamydial infection. The USPSTF does not recammend routine testing in women age 25 and alder at average risk for Chlamydia.
(Choice E) The USFSTF recammends that high-risk sexually active women (age 24 and younger, new ar multiple partners, history of sexually transmitted infections), including those who are pregnant, be screened for gonorrhea. Treatment decreases the risk of premature rupture of membranes, preterm labar, and charioamnianitis. This woman does not fall within the recommended age range for screening and is atherwise at average risk.
(Choice F) All pregnant women should have their fasting blood sugar tested at 24 to 28 weeks of gestation. High-risk patients (marked obesity, family history of diabetes) can be screened earlier in pregnancy.
Educational objective:
The COC recommends that all pregnant wamen withaut caontraindications be vaccinated against influenza.

question: A 16-year-old girl presents far evaluation of acne, which has been getting progressively warse over the past 2 weeks. Her medical history is significant far systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) far which she has been taking prednisone for a recent exacerbation. Hydraxychloroguine is her anly other medicine. She does not use tobacca, alcohol ar drugs and her menstrual cycle is regular. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 110/76 mmHg and her pulse is 72/min. Her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Distributed over the face, arms and trunk are manomaorphous erythematous papules. There are no open or closed comedones. The remainder af the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her acne?
explanation:
This patient has steroid-induced folliculitis, ar steroid acne, secondary to the prednisone she is using for her SLE flare. Steroid acne is characterized by manomaorphous pink papules and absence of comedanes.
(Choice A) Adolescent acne is characterized by open and closed comedones and inflammatory nodules in differing stages of evalution primarily affecting the face, chest and back.
{Choice B) Androgen abuse is a possible cause of bath acne vulgaris and steroid-induced acne. One of the main pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying acne vulgaris is androgen excess. Given her history, steroid acne is mare likely.
(Choice C) In polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) there is an underlying excess of serum androgens. As such, it is commonly associated with acne vulgaris. Other findings in PCOS include irregular menses, anavulation, and hirsutism.
(Choice E) Systemic lupus erythematosus itself is not a common cause of acneiform lesions. The skin finding most classic for SLE is an erythematous malar eruption.
Educational objective:
Systemic and topical corticosteroids can induce an acneifarm eruption characterized by monomarphous, erythematous follicular papules distributed an the face, trunk and extremities. Comedaones are characteristically absent.

question: A 34-year-old sexually active female comes to your office because of urinary frequency and dysuria for two days. She has had two such episodes in the past, each treated with oral antibiotics. Fhysical examination reveals suprapubic tenderness and her urinalysis is positive far nitrite, leukocyte esterase, many WBC, and a maderate amount of bacteria. Which of the following is the most common reason for the higher incidence of urinary tract infections in females than in males?
options: A. Closer proximity of the urethral meatus to the anus in females
B. Frequent use of spermicide and diaphragms in females
C. Shorter urethral length in females
D. Higher post-void urine residual in females
explanation:
Urinary tract infections (UTI) are mare commanly seen in females than males, and half of all adult wamen have a UTI at same time in their life. The high incidence of UTI's in wamen is primarily due ta the shorter length of the female urethra. After the periurethral area becomes colonized by rectal flora, the bacteria ascend to the bladder to cause infection. This is facilitated in females by a short urethra. Predisposing factors for UTI's include alteration of the normal vaginal flara by recent antibiotic use, sexual intercourse, diaphragm or spermicide use, ar a family history of multiple UTI's.
Males, on the other hand, are less likely to develop a UTI mainly because they have a longer urethra than females. They alsa have a drier periurethral environment and antibacterial substances in prostatic fluid, which alsa help to fight off infection.
(Choice A) A shorter distance between the anus and urethra in women is associated with a higher incidence af recurrent UTI's within the female population, but is nat the main reasan for the difference in UTI frequency between men and women.
(Choice B) Spermicide and diaphragm use are risk factors for UTI's in females. A sharter urethral length in females, however, is responsible for their higher frequency of UTl's compared to males.
{Choice D) Increased post-void urine residual is nat associated with a higher incidence of recurrent UTl's in females.
(Choice E) Female hormonal fluctuation is not related to an increased incidence of UTl's in females.
Educational objective:
The increased incidence of urinary tract infections in women is due ta the shorter length of the female urethra compared to males. Other predisposing factars for UTl's include sexual intercourse, recent antibiotic use, the use of spermicidal contraceptives, and a clase proximity of the urethra ta the anus.

question: A 16-year-old girl is brought ta your office by her mother far evaluation of primary amenorrhea. Her older sister had her first period at age 13. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows absense of breast development and external genitalia at Tanner stage 1. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the mast appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
This patient has primary amenarrhea and underdevelopment of secondary sexual characteristics. Isolated amenorrhea with well-developed secondary sexual characteristics can be considered normal up to the age of 16. However, if secondary sexual characteristics are absent as with this patient, work-up should not be delayed. The absence of breast development indicates a lack of estrogen, so measuring estragen levels pravides no additional information.
Primary amenarrhea can be due to either hypothalamic/pituitary abnormalities (central), or to gonadal (peripheral) abnormalities. The distinction can be made by measurement of the FSH level (Choice C). Increased FSH indicates a peripheral cause and decreased FSH indicates a central cause. If amenorrhea is of central arigin, a GnRH stimulation test is then indicated to detect whether the anomaly is of hypothalamic ar pituitary origin. If amenorrhea is of peripheral arigin, karyotyping would be the next step. If FSH is normal, this establishes the diagnosis of ovarian agenesis or dysgenesis. Measurement of LH has no diagnostic value.
Educational objective:
In a patient with primary amenorrhea:
# FSH measurement should be ordered if there is no breast development
# GnRH stimulation test is the next step if FSH is decreased
# Karyotyping is the next step if FSH is increased

question: A 20-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks gestation comes to the physician because of swelling in her hands and ankles. She has no headache visual disturbances or epigastric pain. She has na previous medical problems. She does not use tobacco, alcohal or illicit drugs. Her previous prenatal check-up at 28-weeks gestation was normal. Her medical records show no preexisting hypertension or proteinuria. Her blood pressure is 156/100 mmHg, and after 15 minutes of lateral rest, a repeat reading is 154/98 mmHg. Physical examination shaws 2+ pitting edema in both legs and hands. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Fetal heart tones are audible by Doppler. Labaoratary studies show: Hb 13.0 g/dL, Hct 50%, Flatelets 300,000/mm3, Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 1+ proteinuria, which is new. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The patient described has mild preeclampsia. Mild preeclampsia is defined clinically by hypertension greater than 140/90 mmHg and proteinuria greater than 0.3g/24h (300mg/24h) after the 20th week of gestation. Dependent and nondependent edema is also commanly present though edema is a comman finding in pregnancy in general.
(Choice B) Severe preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension greater than 160/110 mmHg, proteinuria greater than 5g/24h, aliguria, elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia and possibly pulmonary edema.
(Choices C & F) Chronic hypertension in pregnancy implies hypertension that is not pregnancy induced such as essential hypertension. Itis diagnosed when hypertension exists prior to pregnancy ar when it appears before the 20th week of gestation. If proteinuria appears during the course of pregnancy, the candition is then called chranic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia.
(Choice D) Transient hypertension occurs in the second half of pregnancy or during labar and delivery. Proteinuria may be present but does not exceed 300mg/24hr. If at some point the proteinuria exceeds 300mg/24hr, the diagnosis of preeclampsia is made.
(Choice E) Eclampsia is defined as the occurrence of grand mal seizures in patients with either mild ar severe preeclampsia.
Educational objective:
Mild preeclampsia is defined clinically by hypertension greater than 140/30 mmHg and proteinuria greater than 0.3g/24h (300mg/24h) after the 20th week of gestatian.

question: Which of the following is the mast appropriate initial medication to treat her hypertension and proteinuria? (Referring to the patient in the previous question: 20-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks with mild preeclampsia)
explanation:
The most definitive treatment for preeclampsia and eclampsia is delivery of the fetus, but delivery of a fetus at 32 weeks gestation would cause harm to the fetus that is greater than continuing the pregnancy closer to term. Management in this setting would include monitoring and bed rest as well as an antihypertensive medication. Methyldopa has a lang history of safety in pregnancy and is considered the first-line treatment of hypertension in pregnancy. Methyldopa functions as a centrally-acting alpha adrenergic agonist thereby decreasing sympathetic outflow and producing vasodilation.
(Choice A) Lisinopril is an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. ACE inhibitors are absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as they can cause fetal renal dysgenesis and fetal death.
(Choice C) Furosemide and other diuretics are typically avoided in pregnancy as they can prevent the normal physiologic intravascular volume expansion that occurs as a normal function of pregnancy.
(Choice D) Mitroprusside is a pregnancy categary C agent, but its production of cyanide as a metabolic byproduct makes it a less favorable option for use in pregnancy.
{Choice E) Verapamil is a calcium channel blacker and is pregnancy category C, meaning its safety in pregnancy has not yet been established. Of the calcium channel blockers, nifedipine is mare cammanly used than verapamil in pregnancy.
Educational objective:
Methyldopa is a pregnancy category B agent and is the first-line medication far treatment of hypertension in pregnancy.

question: A 17-year-old female comes to the physician's office for a routine physical examination. She has no complaints and has no previous medical problems. She has been having sex since the age of 14 and has had 3 sexual partners so far. Vital signs are stable and physical examination is unremarkable. Fap smear is performed and the report came back as "satisfactary for evaluation” and shows mild dysplasia {low grade intraepithelial lesion). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Repeat Pap smear in 2 weeks
B. Repeat Pap smear in 12 manths
explanation:
The management of a low-grade squamaus epithelial lesion (LSIL) differs based on the age of the patient. In general, LSIL discovered on cervical cytology indicates the presence of cytologically atypical squamaus cells an the cervix. The atypicality of these cells may be due to HPY infection ar cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). CIM is graded as type 1 — 3. The majority of LSIL lesions not attributable simply to HPV infection are CIM 1, which does not require treatment, only observation. Uncommanly, LSIL may be observed in the setting of CIN 2 or 3, which require treatment. In an adolescent female the abnarmal cervical cells are most likely due to HP infection. Because frank cervical cancer in this population is uncammaon, the best management strategy is a follow-up Pap smear in 1 year. Mast LSIL lesions in this population will resolve spontaneausly.
Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL)
(Mild dysplasia (or) CIN 1)
Adolescents -> Repeat Pap in 12 months
Premenopausal woman -> Colposcopy
Postmenopausal woman -> Reflex HPV testing -> (If ‘positive’) Colposcopy
(Choice A) Repeat Pap smear in 2 weeks is not a routine method used to follow-up an abnormal Fap smear.
(Choice C) Reflex HPV testing in this population where the incidence of HPV is quite high is not likely to assist in making or excluding the diagnosis of cervical neoplasia.
(Choice D) Colposcopy is not typically done in adolescents with low-grade lesions as LSIL and ASCUS lesions tend ta resalve spontaneously in the overwhelming majarity of cases. The patient should, however, be monitored far this resolution or a progression of her lesion with a repeat Pap smear in ane year.
(Choice E) Endometrial curettage is a diagnostic test used in making the diagnosis of endometrial cancer. Endocervical curettage is used to obtain tissue far histologic examination following an abnormal Pap smear when a colposcopy is indicated and a lesion can not be identified or when atypical glandular lesions are identified.
Educational objective:
In adolescent females, ASCUS or LSIL cervical lesions are mast likely due to HPV infection. Because frank cervical cancer in this population is uncommon, the best management strategy is a follow-up Pap smear in 1 year.

question: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 28 weeks gestation comes to the physician's office because she has not felt any fetal movements for the past 48 hours. Her pregnancy thus far has been uncomplicated. Prenatal ultrasound at the 12th week of gestation showed an intrauterine gestation consistent with dates and showed no abnormalities. She has no history of trauma. She has no history of serious illness. Review of systems reveals na abnormalities. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or drugs. Fetal heart tones are not heard by Doppler. ‘ital signs are narmal. Which of the following is the mast appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
The patient described has mast likely had an intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD). IUFD is the death of a fetus in utero that occurs after 20 weeks gestation and before the anset of labor. IUFD is suspected when the patient reparts the disappearance of fetal movements, a decrease or stagnation in uterine size or when fetal heart sounds are no longer heard. Beta-hCG levels may continue to be elevated due to ongoing placental production of that harmaone. Ultrasonography is a mare reliable tool for confirming the diagnosis; it demonstrates an absence of fetal movement and fetal cardiac activity.
(Choice A) The diagnosis of IUFD requires confirmation with ultrasonography befare any further action can be taken.
{Choice B) A non-stress test is irrelevant since it is suspected that the fetus is dead. IUFD needs to be canfirmed by demanstrating the absence of fetal heart movement on ultrasonogram.
(Choice C) Serum beta-hCG levels are nat useful because they usually remain elevated due to ongaing placental production.
{Choice D) Monitoring the coagulation profile should be done as IUFD can cause maternal coagulopathy. The diagnosis should first be confirmed by ultrasonography.
Educational objective:
The most appropriate test to canfirm the diagnasis of intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) is real time ultrasanography to demonstrate an absence of fetal movement and cardiac activity.

question: Real time ultrasonography shows no fetal movements and no fetal heart motion. A maternal coagulation profile shows no abnormalities. Induction of labor is performed and the dead fetus is evacuated. Looking at her antenatal chart you noticed that the mother had missed 2 monthly appointments. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement at this time? (Referring to the patient in the previous question with IUFD)
options: A. "Don't warry, there is no increased risk of having a still birth in future pregnancies"
B. "We need to monitor a serial beta-hCG level for next 3 months"
C. "We need to monitor serial fibrinogen levels for next four weeks"
D. "I would recommend an autopsy of fetus and placenta"
E. "It would not have happened if you had good antenatal care"
explanation:
Intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) is the death of a fetus in utero that occurs after 20 weeks gestation and before the anset of labor. It can be caused by a multitude of conditions such as hypertensive disarders, diabetes mellitus, placental and card complications, antiphasphalipid syndrome, congenital anomalies and fetal infections such as the TORCH infections ar listeriosis. However, the cause remains unknown in 50% of cases. tis very important to try to diagnose the cause of the fetal demise after the first episode in arder to prevent, if possible, a recurrence of the same issue in any subsequent pregnancies. Autopsy of the fetus and placenta should be performed.
(Choice A) There is a 1 ta 8 % risk of recurrent still birth in mothers who have previously experienced IUFD.
(Choice B) Serial beta-HCG manitaring is required if there is a suspicion far malar pregnancy.
(Choice C) Serial testing of fibrinogen levels is performed to detect a consumptive coagulopathy early in its course in patients with IUFD managed with watchful expectancy. The fetus in this case has already been evacuated, so the risk of coagulopathy has been addressed.
(Choice E) Blaming the parent for fetal death is inappropriate under any circumstances. If actions taken by the parent possibly caused inadvertent demise of their fetus, then education should be undertaken to ensure that such a parent will have an improved chance at a successful subsequent pregnancy.
Educational objective:
A search should be undertaken to determine the cause after the first episode of intrauterine fetal demise. Autopsy of the fetus and placenta should be performed in all cases of stillbirth with the permission of the parents.

question: A 22-year-old woman presents with complaints of vaginal discharge and severe vulvar pruritus. She is atherwise healthy. Physical examination reveals a thin, malodorous vaginal discharge and marked vulvar and vaginal erythema. The pH of the vaginal discharge is 5.5. Microscopic examination of the discharge is most likely to reveal which of the following:
explanation:
This patient has trichomonas vaginitis, a sexually transmitted infection that causes malodorous, gray-green, thin, frothy vaginal discharge, as well as vaginal and vulvar pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia. Affected male partners are typically asymptomatic. On examination the vulva and vaginal walls are edematous and hyperemic. Diagnosis is made by wet-mount preparation of the discharge with visualization of the responsible organism. Trichomonas vaginalis is as a highly motile, pear-shaped organism with 3 to 5 flagella. Itis larger than WEBCs and smaller than vaginal epithelial cells. Trichomonas infection often disrupts the normal vaginal milieu, causing pH increases to the 5.0 - 6.0 range.
(Choice A) Candida vaginitis causes a discharge that is non-malodarous, white, and thick in consistency. The pH of the discharge is usually between 4.0 and 4.5.
{Choice C) Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells coated with the bacterium Gardnerella vaginalis. If seen on microscopic exam af vaginal discharge, this finding is diagnostic of bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis may cause abnormal elevation of the vaginal pH, but pruritus and inflammation are not characteristic.
(Choice D) Multinucleated giant cells are characteristic of genital herpes. A vesicular rash is seen an exam.
(Choice E) Eosinophils are nat seen in Trichamanas vaginitis.
Educational objective:
Trichomanas infection causes inflammation, pruritus, and a thin malodorous vaginal discharge. In contrast, bacterial vaginesis does nat cause inflammation, and candida vaginitis causes a discharge that is thick and white.

question: A 57-year-old woman comes ta the physician's office for evaluation of vaginal dryness, burning and dyspareunia. She also has dysuria and increased urinary frequency. The symptoms have been present for several months but have intensified recently. She has tried over-the-counter lubricants with little relief. Her last menstrual period was seven years ago. She takes hydrochlorathiazide for hypertension and pravastatin for hyperchalesterolemia. Physical examination shows scarce pubic hair and reduced elasticity and turgor of the vulvar skin. Pale, dry and smooth vaginal epithelium is nated. Urine dipstick is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Atrophic vaginitis is a clinical diagnosis made based on histary and physical exam findings. Typical symptoms include vaginal dryness, pruritus, dyspareunia, dysuria, and urinary frequency. Pelvic exam in atrophic vaginitis is characterized by pale, dry and smooth vaginal epithelium, scarce pubic hair, and loss of the labial fat pad. This condition occurs in post-menopausal females as a result of decreased estrogen levels. This patient's history and physical are typical of atrophic vaginitis. Many symptoms of atrophic vaginitis can also be seen in urinary tract infection (UTI). This patient's urine dipstick rules aut UTI, and therefore it is appropriate to proceed with treatment for atrophic vaginitis. Use of moisturizers and lubricants is an appropriate first step in management of mild atrophic vaginitis; for moderate to severe cases the first line treatment is local low-dose vaginal estrogen therapy (Choice D).
{Choice A) Ciprofloxacin is an appropriate treatment for UTI. Many of this patient's symptoms (burning, dysuria, and urinary frequency) can be seen in UTI. However, her urine dipstick is negative, making atrophic vaginitis the mast likely diagnosis.
(Choice B) Metronidazole is appropriate for the treatment of Trichomonas. This patient's exam does nat show findings consistent with trichamaonas, and her history is more consistent with atrophic vaginitis.
(Choice C) Discontinuation of hydrochlorothiazide will not ameliorate the symptoms of atrophic vaginitis.
(Choice E) Steroids have no role in the management of atrophic vaginitis, but high-potency corticosteroid cream is used in the management of vulvar lichen planus and lichen sclerosus. While these conditions may present with some of the symptoms seen in this patient, her physical exam findings and post-menopausal status are most consistent with atrophic vaginitis.
Educational objective:
Suspect atrophic vaginitis in post-menopausal females with symptoms of vaginal dryness and dysuria, and physical exam findings of pale, dry vaginal mucosa, diminished labial fat pad, and scarce pubic hair. Moderate and severe cases require local estrogen therapy.

question: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes for a routine prenatal visit. According to her history, she is at 18-weeks gestation. Her family history is significant for Down syndrome an her maternal side. She does not use tobacco, alcohol ar drugs. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination is unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies show a decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFF). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Alpha-fetopraotein (AFF) measurement can be used to screen for fetal anomalies. Increased levels are seen in the presence of neural tube defects, abdominal wall defects (gastroschisis, omphalocele), multiple gestation and inaccurate gestational age. Low levels of MSAFF can be associated with chromosomal anomalies, such as Down syndrome and trisomy 18, and inaccurate gestational dates. Ultrasonagraphy should first be performed in the patient described to rule out inaccurate dates. Other tests can be done after the dates have been confirmed by an ultrasound.
(Choice A) Amniocentesis is indicated in cases where the MSAFF or triple/quadruple screen is abnarmal, but only after ultrasonography has ascertained gestational age accuracy and ruled out nonviable pregnancy ar multiple gestation. It is best performed between 16 and 20 weeks gestation.
(Choice B) Charianic villus sampling is indicated far early screening in women with known genetic diseases ar wha have had children affected by a genetic condition. Itis performed between 10 and 12 weeks gestation, and therefore offers the advantage of a first trimester termination of pregnancy if the fetus is affected.
(Choice D) Cordocentesis is used for rapid karyotype analysis, or when fetal blood dyscrasias, such as fetal anemia and Rhesus isoimmunization, are suspected. In the present case, ultrasound should be performed first to rule out causes of MSAFP elevation ather than genetic anomalies.
{Choice E) An estradiol level has no clinical value in pregnancy. Serum estriol levels can be measured in pregnancy along with MSAFF and beta-hCG (triple test] as a screening tool for chromosomal anomalies in the fetus.
Educational objective:
If maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFF) levels are abnarmal in a pregnant patient, the next step is ultrasonography ta confirm gestational age, detect fetal structural anomalies, detect multiple gestation and confirm a viable pregnancy.

question: A 24-year-old woman presents to your office with a self-palpated breast lump. She discovered the mass 2 days ago while taking a shower and noted that it is mildly tender Her menstrual periods are regular, occurring every 26 days. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 3 weeks ago. Her past medical histary is insignificant. She has no family history of breast cancer. Physical examination reveals a lump in the superior auter quadrant of the right breast without palpable lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most reasonable next step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Ask her to return shortly after the menstrual period
C. Proceed with fine needle aspiration biopsy
E. Reassure that the mass is benign and no follow-up is necessary
explanation:
A self-palpated breast mass is a very comman clinical presentation of various benign and malignant breast diseases. Unfortunately, it is usually very difficult to differentiate a benign breast mass from cancer by history and physical examination. Further work-up is frequently necessary (choice E).
A young woman who presents with a breast lump can be asked to return after her menstrual period far reexamination if na obvious signs of malignancy are present. If the mass decreases in size after the menstrual period, the probability of a benign disease is very high. Otherwise, it is advisable to proceed with ultrasonography, fine needle aspiration biopsy (choice C) and/or excisional biopsy (choice D).
Mammagraphy is usually nat helpful in interpreting the mass because the density of breast tissue is high in young wamen (choice B).
Educational Objective:
A young woman who presents with a breast lump can be asked ta return after her menstrual period far reexamination (which may reveal regression of the mass) if no obvious signs of malignancy are present.

question: A 76-year-old woman presents with complaints of severe vulvar itching for the past six months. She has tried aver-the-counter topical lubricants without relief. Physical examination reveals numerous vulvar excariations. The vulvar skin is thin, dry and white in color. The labia minora are difficult ta visualize. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Lichen sclerasus (lichen sclerosus et atrophicus, LS&A) is a chranic inflammatory condition of the anogenital region that most commanly affects women. This condition may have an autoimmune pathogenesis. Itis characterized clinically by anogenital discomfort including pruritus, dyspareunia, dysuria and painful defecation. Physical examination reveals porcelain-white polygonal macules and patches with an atrophic, "cigarette paper" quality. Sclerosus and scarring can lead to obliteration of the labia minora and clitoris and a decrease in the diameter of the introitus.
While the diagnosis can readily be made clinically, vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) occurs mare commonly in wamen with LS&A. When the diagnosis is in question, punch biopsy of any suspicious lesions should be performed.
(Choice A) Vaginal Pap smear can be utilized to assess for intravaginal malignancies.
(Choice C) Radical vulvectomy is reserved for the treatment of high-risk vulvar malignancies.
{Choice D) Estrogen cream is helpful in the treatment of menopause-related atrophic vaginitis, which can also be a cause of vaginal pruritus and dyspareunia.
(Choice E) Vet mount smear is useful in making the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis, trichomaoniasis ar vaginal candidiasis.
Educational objective:
Lichen sclerosus most commanly affects postmenopausal women and manifests with vulvar pruritus and discomfort. Exam shows porcelain-white atrophy. Biopsy should be considered ta rule out vulvar SCC.

question: A diagnosis of lichen sclerosus is made. Which of the following is the mast appropriate next step in management? (Referring to the patient in the previous question: 76-year-old with lichen sclerosus)
explanation:
Lichen sclerosus (lichen sclerosus et atrophicus, LS&A) is a chronic inflammatary condition of the anogenital region that most commonly affects women. LS8A is considered a premalignant lesion of the vulva as vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) accurs with greater frequency in these patients as compared to the general population. As such, surveillance with regular clinical examinations and biopsies of suspicious lesions is necessary.
LS&A is ane of the few conditions for which use of high-potency topical steroids an the genitals is encouraged. A class | topical corticosteroid in aintment form should be applied twice daily for four weeks, at which paint transition to a less potent topical steroid ar topical calcineurin inhibitor for maintenance therapy is appropriate.
(Choice A) Radical vulvectomy is reserved far the treatment of high-risk vulvar malignancies such as invasive squamous cell carcinoma ar melanoma. Less disfiguring procedures can be used for basal cell carcinomas and smaller squamous cell carcinomas.
(Choice C) Estrogen cream is helpful in the treatment of menopause-related atrophic vaginitis, which can also be a cause of vaginal pruritus and dyspareunia.
(Choice D) Cryotherapy is commonly utilized to treat genital warts.
{Choice E) Clotrimazole cream is useful in the treatment of vaginal candidiasis.
Educational objective:
High-potency topical steroids are considered first-line therapy for lichen sclerosus.

question: A 30-year-old G2 P1 woman at 38 weeks gestation presents to the hospital complaining of regular and painful uterine contractions that started two hours earlier. Pelvic examination reveals bulging membranes, and her cervix is 50% effaced and dilated to 3 cm. Her pregnancy was complicated by first tnmester hemarrhage of unknown cause. Her past medical history is unremarkable After placing a fetal heart monitor and an external tacometer on the patient, you note 3 separate 15 beat/min decreases in the fetal heart rate not coinciding with uterine contractions, each lasting for 25 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Oxygen administration and change in maternal position
explanation:
Variable decelerations represent a nan-reassuring fetal heart rate (FHR) pattern, and are characterized by the erratic onset of abrupt slowing of the FHR in association with uterine contractions. They are the most commanly encountered FHR deceleration seen in pregnancy, and are thought to be the result of umbilical card compression. Variable decelerations usually accur during the anset of uterine contractions. Mild ar moderate variable decelerations are of shart duration, shallow, and are associated with a rapid return to baseline FHR. Persistent decelerations to less than 70 beats/min and of long duration are concerning far fetal hypoxia.
The first step in the presence of variable decelerations is to administer oxygen and have the mother change her position so that she is lying on her side. If the variable decelerations persist, the patient should be placed in the Trendelenburg position and the presenting fetal part should be elevated. Persistent variable decelerations may require amnicinfusion, which consists of the infusion of fluid into the amniotic cavity.
(Choice B) Rupture of the membranes will result in the loss of amniotic fluid and may warsen fetal cord Compression.
{Choice C) Amnininfusion may be indicated if persistent variable decelerations are present, but should be used anly after mare conservative measures have failed.
(Choice D) Fetal scalp pH testing should be performed to assess for fetal hypoxia if the abnormal FHR pattern persists after the initial measures aof position change, oxygen administration, and discontinuation of axytocin have been tried.
(Choice E) Cesarean section is indicated when fetal distress is confirmed. The patient in this case has had anly three decelerations, and mare conservative measures should be attempted first.
Educational objective:
The most appropriate first steps in the management of variable decelerations are oxygen administration and change in maternal position.

question: A 15-year-old girl is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. She is otherwise healthy and has no previous medical problems. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normal breast development, normal pubic and axillary hair, and a blind vagina; the uterus and adnexae could not be appreciated. Pelvic ultrasonography reveals 2 ovaries and na uterus is seen. The karyotype is 46 XK. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient has a female phenotype but lacks a normal vagina and uterus, which narrows the etiology of her primary amenarrhea to mullerian agenesis, androgen insensitivity, or 5-alpha-reductase deficiency. The karyotype Is the determining test, with bath androgen insensitivity and 5-alpha-reductase deficiency being seen in patients with a XY genotype. This patient's genotype is Xx, which leaves mullerian agenesis as the best explanation for her condition. The mullerian duct normally leads to the development of the proximal vagina and the uterus; therefore patients with mullerian agenesis normally have a blind ended vagina with little to no uterine tissue.
(Choice B) Patients with androgen insensitivity have a male XY genotype but there is an abnormality in the androgen receptor. The external genitalia develop as female, but mullerian inhibiting factar is still secreted by the testes which prevents the development of internal female organs.
(Choice C) Fatients with 5-alpha-reductase deficiency cannot convert testosterone ta the mare potent dihydrotestosterane (DHT). They have a male XY genotype and female external genitalia, but typically show virilization at puberty.
(Choice D) An imperfarate hymen can cause primary amenorrhea but can generally be distinguished from mullerian agenesis by the distal location of the vaginal blockage. Patients have a normal uterus on ultrasound.
(Choice E) Patients with Turner's syndrome have a xO genotype and da not have normal ovaries on ultrasound.
Educational objective:
Patients with mullerian agenesis have a blind ended vaginal pouch with little or no uterine tissue and a xx genotype.

question: A 24-year-old woman delivered a healthy baby by vaginal delivery at 36 weeks gestation. She had a prolonged premature rupture of the membranes, and mid forceps application was required during delivery. On the second postpartum day she complained of fever and chills. She cannot breast-feed because her "nipples are tender”. Her temperature is 38.5C (101 .3F), blood pressure is 120/55 mmHg and pulse is 92/min. Bimanual examination shows tender uterus and foul-smelling lachia. Her nipples are cracked but without surrounding erythema ar warmth. Physical examination otherwise shows na abnormalities. Which of the following is the mast likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The patient described is experiencing postpartum endometritis. A puerperal infection should be suspected if a waman experiences a fever greater than 38 C (100.4 F) outside of the first 24 hours postpartum. Risk factors for endometritis include, but are not limited to prolonged rupture of the membranes (= 24 haurs), prolonged labor (= 12 hours), cesarean section and use of intrauterine pressure catheters or fetal scalp electrodes. This patient has at least two of these risk factors. Clinically, endometritis is characterized by fever, uterine tenderness, foul smelling lochia and leukocytosis. Broad spectrum antibiotics are required to treat this typically palymicrobial infection.
(Choice A) While the normal postpartum period is assaciated with persistent vaginal discharge (lochia), this discharge should steadily resolve over the first two weeks and should never be fouksmelling.
(Choice B) Puerperal mastitis occurs in breastfeeding mathers and can begin with a sare or fissured nipple, but this diagnosis would be unlikely this soon after delivery.
(Choices D & E) Deep venous thrombosis and aspiration pneumonia would be associated with physical examination findings consistent with each of these diagnoses. The physical examination in this patient is narmal ather than the abnormalities such as uterine tenderness and foul-smelling lachia that indicate a puerperal infection rather than one of these conditions.
Educational objective:
Endometritis is characterized clinically be fever and uterine tenderness in the postpartum period and is often associated with foul-smelling lochia. Risk factors include prolonged ROM, prolonged labor, operative vaginal delivery and caesarian section among athers.

question: Which of the following pathogens is mast likely responsible for this patient's current condition? (Referring to the patient in the previous question with postpartum endometritis)
explanation:
This patient has postpartum endometritis. Endometritis is the most common cause of puerperal fever on the 2nd and 3rd day postpartum. Endometritis is a polymicrobial infection caused by a combination of gram positive and gram negative organisms, aerobic and anaerobic organisms and occasionally other arganisms such as Mycoplasma and Chlamydia.
(Choice A) Chlamydia irachomatis is a commaon cause of pelvic inflammatory disease in nonpregnant women, and can uncommoaonly cause postpartum endometritis. Postpartum endometritis due to Chlamydia aften accurs many days following delivery, nat in the first 48 — 72 hours.
{Choice B) Group B Streptococcus is a potential cause of both postpartum endometritis and neanatal sepsis. Women are often screened for this organism and treated if colonized befare delivery. Despite this screening, GBS can be isolated along with other organisms in approximately one-third of cases of postpartum endometritis.
(Choice C) Neisseria gonorrhea is one gram-negative organism that can be associated with postpartum endometritis. It occurs in less than 10% of cases.
(Choice D) Staphylococcus aureus 1s nat commanly isalated in cultures from wamen with endometritis. Staphylococcus epidermidis, however, can often be recavered as part of a polymicrobial infection in such women.
Educational objective:
Postpartum endometritis is most commonly a palymicrobial infection composed of gram positive and gram negative organisms, aerobic and anaerobic organisms and occasionally ather organisms.

question: Which of the following is the mast appropriate initial therapy for this patient? (Referring to the patient in the previous questions with postpartum endometritis)
explanation:
Endometritis is a polymicrobial infection caused by a combination of gram positive and gram negative arganisms, aerobic and anaerobic organisms and occasionally other organisms such as Mycoplasma and Chlamydia. Commonly isolated organisms include group B streptococci, group D streptocacei, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Escherichia coli, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Gardnerella vaginalis, Bacteroides fragilis, peptastreptococci and peptacocci. Given the palymicrobial nature of postpartum endometrial infections, the most appropriate therapy is intravenous clindamycin combined with an intravenous aminoglycoside such as gentamicin.
(Choice A) Vancomycin is only effective against gram-positive organisms and gentamicin provides excellent gram-negative coverage, but this regimen would not be as effective against anaerobic arganisms.
{Choice B) Clindamycin and metronidazole are both active against anaerobic organisms but would not be effective in eliminating gram-negative aerobic organisms.
{Choice C) Vancomycin and clindamycin would not provide adequate coverage of gram-negative aerobic organisms.
(Choice E) Ceftriaxone and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for pelvic inflammatory disease. The cephalosporin treats MN. gonorrhoeae while the macrolide treats C. frachomatis.
Educational objective:
The treatment of choice far postpartum endometritis, which is a polymicrobial infection, is intravenous clindamycin and gentamicin.

question: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department because of acute onset intense uterine contractions and vaginal bleeding. She has been followed closely for pre-eclampsia since her 32nd week of gestation. Her temperature is 37.0 C {98 7F), blood pressure is 140/86mmHg, pulse is 92/min and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination shows uterine tenderness and hyperactivity and moderate vaginal bleeding. Pelvic examination shows an effaced and 3cm dilated cervix. Ultrasonography shows a fundic placenta and a fetus in the cephalic position. Fetal heart tracing shows 140/min with goad long-term and beat-to-beat variability. After initial resuscitation the bleeding is stopped. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Vaginal delivery with augmentation of labor, if necessary
C. Perform tocolysis and schedule cesarean section within 48 hours
explanation:
According ta the clinical signs and the associated pre-eclampsia, the patient most likely has a placental abruption. Ultrasonography detects only 25% of cases of abruption, and it is mare useful in ruling out placenta previa than in diagnosing abruption. Placental abruption is a condition that can progress rapidly; so careful monitoring of both the mother and the fetus is mandatory. Once the diagnosis is made, a large-baore IV line as well as a Foley catheter must be placed. Blood products should always be available. Patients with placental abruption in labar must be managed aggressively to insure a rapid vaginal delivery because this will remave the retroplacental hemorrhage which acts as the impetus for DIC and hemarrhage in the setting of placental abruption. Cesarean section is used only when there are obstetric indications for that procedure ar when there is a rapid deterioration of the state of either the mother or the fetus. In this case, the patient is stable, the fetus is at term and doing well, and labor has already started (presence of cervical changes), so a vaginal delivery can be attempted and oxytocin can be used ta augment labor.
(Choices B & C) Cesarean section is indicated if the mother and/or the fetus are not stable, and the risk of serious complications is imminent, or in the case of obstetrical contraindications to vaginal delivery (placenta previa, dystocia, breech presentation, prior caesarian). Furthermore, delivery in this case should be expedited; there is no reason to perform tocalysis.
(Choice D) Forceps can be used if there is dystocia, but the cervix is only 3 cm dilated and it is too early to know whether the forceps will be necessary or not.
(Choice E) Because the fetus is at term and labor is progressing, there is no reason to wait. Additionally, because of the maternal and fetal mortality associated with placental abruption, the patient described must be managed immediately.
Educational objective:
Patients with placental abruption in labor must be managed aggressively to insure a rapid vaginal delivery. Cesarean section is used only when there are obstetric indications, or when there is a rapid deteriaration of the state of either the mather ar the fetus and labar is in an early stage.

question: A wealthy executive donates five million dollars far the prevention of intrauterine growth restriction in the local county. Spending this money on which of the following programs would prevent the greatest number of cases of fetal grawth restriction (FGR) in the population?
explanation:
Smoking is the single most prevalent preventable cause of FGR in the United States. One in three cases of FGR is attributable to smoking, and women who smoke while pregnant have a three to four-fold increased risk of having a growth restricted infant.
(Choice A) Smoking is much mare common during pregnancy than is alcoholism. Significant alcohal consumption during pregnancy is associated with the fetal alcohol syndrome, which is characterized by growth restriction accompanied by midfacial hypoplasia and CNS deficits.
{Choice C) Maternal malnutrition must be severe in order to produce fetal growth restriction; this is not commanly observed in the United States.
(Choice D) Hypertension is a prevalent cause of fetal growth restriction, but it is not as commonly associated with FGR as is smoking. Hypertension in pregnancy is not only associated with FGR, but it is also associated with severe conditions that pose risk to the mother such as preeclampsia and eclampsia.
(Choice E) The most commonly identified infectious agent associated with FGR is cytomegalovirus (CMV), which can not be effectively prevented ar treated in most cases.
Educational objective:
Cigarette smoking is the most common preventable cause of fetal growth restriction in the United States.

question: A 20-year-old, G1P0, woman at 35 weeks gestation comes to the hospital because of regular uterine contractions and passage of clear fluid per vagina. She has no other symptoms. Her pregnancy thus far has been uncomplicated. Her temperature is 38.2 C (100.7 F), blood pressure is 120/68 mmHg, pulse is 110/min and respirations are 17/min. Speculum examination shows a closed cervix and clear fluid pooling in the vaginal farnix. The pH of the fluid is 7.5. Fetal heart monitoring shows a rate of 165/min and uterine cantractions occurring every 3-4 minutes. Initial laboratory studies show: Hemoglokin 10.2 g/L, Platelets 198,000/mm3, Leukocyte count 18,500/mm3, Neutrophils 86%, Lymphocytes 14%. Which of the following is the mast likely diagnasis?
explanation:
The patient described has experienced spontaneous premature rupture of the membranes (FROM), which is defined as a rupture of the amniotic membranes before 37 weeks of gestation but with the onset of labor, as evidenced by her regular uterine contractions. Normal amniatic fluid pH is 7.0 to 7.5, while normal vaginal pH is 4.5 to 5.5, so the more neutral pH of the fluid described in this patient indicates it is of amniatic arigin. One af the risks associated with PPROM is intraamniotic infection. Intraamnictic infection (chorioamnionitis) should be suspected in mathers presenting with prolonged or premature rupture of the membranes, fever and any one of the following findings: maternal tachycardia (= 100/min), fetal tachycardia (= 160/min), maternal leukocytasis (= 15,000/mm3), uterine tenderness or foul-smelling amniotic fluid.
(Choice A) Abruptio placenta commanly presents with bleeding from the vagina: though, a subset of placental abruptions is concealed and does not cause clinical bleeding. Abdominal ar back pain, uterine tenderness and abnormal uterine contractions are typical. Fetal distress due to poor placental perfusion may be evident.
(Choice C) A urinary tract infection may cause leukocytosis if the infection was ascending. Dysuria would likely be present and fetal tachycardia would not be expected.
(Choice D) Trichomonas vaginitis is not associated with obstetric complications other than a possible association with early labor.
{Choice E) Maternal leukocytosis (=15 000/cmm) with fever and fetal tachycardia are not components of normal labar.
Educational objective:
Intraamnictic infection should be suspected in the setting of prolonged or premature rupture of the membranes when maternal fever, leukocytosis, uterine tenderness or tachycardia is detected. Fetal tachycardia is anather feature of charicamnianitis.

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? (Referring to the patient in the previous question with chorioamnionitis)
explanation:
The patient described has experienced spontaneous preterm rupture of the membranes (FROM) that has been complicated by an intraamniatic infection {charioamnianitis). The mast impartant first intervention is treatment of the mather with broad spectrum antibiotics as chorioamnianitis is frequently a palymicrobial infection. The preferred regimen includes a combination of intravenous clindamycin and gentamicin. Concomitantly with the administration of antibiotics delivery of the fetus should be expedited as the fetus in question is near term (35 weeks gestation) and the amniotic membrane has ruptured. The most appropriate means of expediting labor in this case would be administration of oxytocin as the patient is already experiencing regular uterine contractions and appears to be in the first stage of labor.
(Choice A) Tocolysis would be contraindicated in this setting.
(Choice B) Betamethasone administered in an effort to imprave fetal lung maturity would have little benefit beyond 32-34 weeks gestational age.
(Choice C) While delivery should be expedited in this case, caesarean section should be reserved for cases where fetal distress is evident. Fetal tachycardia is a sign of maternal infection.
(Choice E) Expectant management may be attempted if a fetus is not yet viable pravided antibiotic therapy is successful in eradicating the infection. Once the membranes have ruptured, however, delivery typically follows.
Educational objective:
The most appropriate treatment of charioamnionitis associated with premature rupture of the membranes is systemic, broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy and expedited delivery of the fetus.

question: A 30-year-old African-American waman with type-1 diabetes and hypertension comes to the physician's office after obtaining a positive result from a home pregnancy test. She takes insulin and enalapril. She does nat use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37.2 C {99.0F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Her BUN is 18 mg/dL and creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL. A repeat B-HCG test performed in the office confirms pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Stop enalapril and start furosemide
B. Continue enalapril and add methyldopa
C. Stop enalapril and start labetalal
D. Stop enalapril and start losartan
explanation:
This pregnant female has essential hypertension which preceded pregnancy. The guidelines far essential hypertension during pregnancy recommend that ACE-inhibitars and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) be discontinued. Both ACE-inhibitars and ARBs are teratogenic throughout the pregnancy, increasing the risk of aligghydramnios and damage to fetal kidneys. Recommended anti-hypertensives during pregnancy include labetalal and methyldopa. Therefore, in this patient, enalapril should be replaced with labetalol. In pregnant females with essential hypertension and BF <=120/80, it is appropriate to consider tapering or discontinuing all anti-hypertensives. Far BF above this value, continuation of anti-hypertensive therapy is appropriate. If a pregnant patient presents with essential hypertension and is not currently on anti-hypertensives it is anly necessary to begin anti-hypertensive therapy if the BP is consistently above 150 systolic or 95 diastolic.
(Choice A) While discontinuing enalapril is appropriate, replacement with furosemide is nat. Furosemide, a loop diuretic, is not amongst the first-line agents for management of essential hypertension in pregnant ar non-pregnant patients. Also, volume depletion should be avoided in pregnant patients.
(Choices B, D & E) Losartan is an ARB. Both ACE-inhibitors and AREs have been shown to have teratogenic effects and should be avoided in pregnancy. Therefare, initiating losartan ar continuing current therapy are both inappropriate.
Educational objective:
ACE inhibitors and ARBs are contraindicated in pregnancy. The first-line agents for management of essential hypertension during pregnancy are labetalal and methyldopa.

question: A 23-year-old G1P0 female presents far her first prenatal visit at 14 weeks gestation. A pap smear is done at that time and a high grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) is seen at cytology. A test for HP discloses the presence of a strain with high oncogenic risk. A satisfactory colposcopy is done and shows na site of abnormalities. At this time the next best step is:
explanation:
During pregnancy the primary goal of colposcopy is the exclusion af invasive cervical cancer. The management of any woman with a cytologic specimen suggesting HSIL consists of colposcopy and directed biopsy. Amang women with HSIL cytology results, 1-2% harbar invasive cancer. The patient alsa has the presence of an ancogenic strain of HPY and is therefore considered an especially high risk patient. If the initial biopsy is negative, a repeat colposcopy and biopsy should be done at 6-8 weeks after delivery.
{Choice A) LEER procedure is an excisional therapy and is recommended for all patients except adolescents and pregnant woman with HSIL on Pap smear but without CIM Il or greater on biopsy since the abnormal area may have been missed by the biopsy. Excisions in pregnant women should be considered only if a lesion suggestive of invasive cancer is detected at colposcopy.
{Choice B) Repeating the Pap smear will not change management of the patient; a repeat colposcopy is still required after delivery.
(Choice C) There is no indication for termination of pregnancy with an abnarmal pap smear.
(Choice E) Endocervical curettage is contraindicated in pregnant patients.
Educational objective:
During pregnancy, the primary goal of colposcopy is the exclusion of invasive cancer. Any woman with a cytologic specimen suggesting HSIL should undergo colposcopy and directed biopsy. If the biopsy is negative, a second biopsy is recommended 6-8 weeks after delivery.

question: A 28-year-old woman comes ta the physician far routine physical examination and a Pap smear. She has had multiple sexual partners and uses barrier methods for contraception. She was treated far chlamydial cervicitis four months ago. She has na other medical problems. Pelvic examination is unremarkable and a Pap smear was performed. A week later the result came as "satisfactory for evaluation" and shows mild dysplasia (low grade intraepithelial lesion). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Repeat Pap smear in 2 weeks
B. Repeat Fap smear in 12 months
explanation:
Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL)
(Mild dysplasia (or) CIN 1)
Adolescents -> Repeat Pap in 12 months
Premenopausal woman -> Colposcopy
Postmenopausal woman -> Reflex HPV testing -> (If ‘positive’) Colposcopy
The management of a low-grade squamous epithelial lesion (LSIL) differs based on the age of the patient. In general, LSIL discovered on cervical cytology indicates the presence of cytologically atypical squamous cells an the cervix. The atypicality of these cells may be due to HPV infection or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). CIN is graded as type 1 —3. The majarity of LSIL lesions nat attributable simply to HPV infection are CIN 1, which does not require treatment, anly observation. Uncommanly, LSIL may be observed in the setting of CIN 2 or 3, which require treatment. In a nonadolescent, premenopausal woman, LSIL should be followed by colposcopy in order to biopsy the lesion and rule out CIN 2 or 3.
(Choice A) Repeat Pap smear in 2 weeks is not a routine method used to follow-up an abnormal Pap smear.
(Choice B) Repeating the Fap smear in 12 manths is appropriate in the setting of a normal Pap smear, a smear revealing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance and LSIL in adolescent females or high-risk HP'/-neqgative postmenopausal females. The risk of cancer is very low in adolescent woman and the LSIL is most often due to transient HPV infection. If a repeat Pap (after 12 months) is also abnormal then the colposcopy should be performed.
(Choice C) Reflex HPV testing should be carried out in postmenopausal women with LSIL, and if positive, should be followed by colposcopy. HPY testing is most commonly positive in premenapausal wamen; therefore, it does not decrease the frequency of colposcopy referrals and is of little use as the initial test for LSIL evaluation. Postmenopausal woman are unlikely to have transient HPY infection.
(Choice D) Cone biopsy (conization) can be accomplished by cold knife, laser or electrosurgical techniques. This procedure is used ta treat cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. The benefit of this treatment modality is that it allows histologic evaluation of the entire cervical transformation zone.
Educational objective:
Cervical dysplasia in a high risk (post-adolescent, premenopausal) patient should be investigated with colposcopy.

question: A 25-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of constant pelvic and low sacral back pain for several months. The pain is usually warse premenstrually. She tried over the counter anti-inflammataory medications but had little relief. She has been in a monogamous relationship with her boyfriend far the past 4 years. She has no fever ar abnormal vaginal discharge. Her temperature is 37.2 C (98.9 F), and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender posterior vaginal fornix and pain upan uterine mation. Complete blood count is normal. Pelvic ultrasonogram is normal. Which of the following is mast appropriate diagnostic test in her management?
explanation:
The patient described is exhibiting a classic presentation for endometriosis. Patients with endometriosis may frequently be asymptomatic, but when symptoms are present, they typically include chronic pelvic pain that is warse in the premenstrual period, dysmenarrhea and pain with sexual intercourse ar defecation. Examination may reveal rectovaginal tenderness ar tenderness with movement of the uterus due to the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue in the rectovaginal septum and the pelvic peritoneum, anteriar and posterior cul-de-sac and uterosacral ligaments. Laparoscopy is the gold standard for making the diagnosis of endometriosis.
(Choice A) Endometrial biopsy is used to diagnosis endometrial cancer. As endometriosis is defined as the presence of endometrial tissue outside of the uterus, a biopsy from within the uterus will not be able to make the diagnosis.
{Choice C) CA 125 is elevated in endometriosis and levels tend to correlate with the severity of endometriosis, but it is an inadequate tool far making the diagnosis of endometriosis as it has a poor sensitivity.
(Choice D) A hysterosalpingogram will fail to detect endometriosis because this study explores the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes but will give no information about the presence of endometrial tissue outside of the uterus.
{Choice E) There is no known association between beta hCG levels and endometriosis. Serial hCG levels are performed in malar pregnancy ta prove that a mole or choriocarcinama has been completely eliminated fallawing surgical evacuation of the uterus.
(Choice F) CT scanning is unable to sufficiently distinguish between soft tissues to make the diagnosis of endometriosis. Similarly, ultrasound is an inadequate tool for making the diagnosis of endometriosis as itis unable to reliably demonstrate endometriomas and adhesions caused by endometriosis. MRI with contrast may have some merit.
Educational objective:
Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis.

question: This patient is at risk of developing of which of the following? (Referring to the patient in the previous question with endometriosis)
explanation:
The patient described has signs and symptoms classic for endometriosis. Fatients with endometriosis are at an increased risk of decreased fertility or infertility. Up to 30% of females being evaluated far infertility are found to have endometriosis. Possible mechanisms for impaired fertility in these patients include adhesion formation within the peritoneum that interferes with the normal transfer of oocytes from the ovarian surface to the fallopian tubes, endometrial factors within the uterus that may provide a suboptimal environment far implantation and hormanal issues that have yet to be determined that may affect avarian function.
(Choice A) Risk factors for endometrial carcinoma include advancing age, use of unopposed estrogen in the past, prolonged use of tamaxifen, obesity, nulliparity and polycystic ovarian syndrome (Stein-Leventhal syndrome).
(Choice B) Risk factors for breast cancer include a positive family history, mutations in BRCAT, BRCAZ or p53, early menarche, late menopause, prolonged hormone replacement therapy, nulliparity and uncomman genetic diseases such as Cowden syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia.
